Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Scale Fluid Turbulence-Scalar Mixing Dynamics in Gas-Phase Turbulent Jets

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336761
Sutton

The objective of this project is to quantify the multi-scale dynamics governing the mixing of a passive scalar quantity by turbulent fluid motion. Specifically, the time- and scale-dependent coupling between fluid turbulence and the scalar field within gas-phase shear flows will be investigated with simultaneous high-speed (> 10 kHz acquisition rate) 3D velocity and 2D conserved scalar imaging. Turbulent scalar mixing is ubiquitous in nature and engineering processes and has been a subject of research for more than sixty years; however, the underlying physics and governing mechanisms producing the observed phenomenology remain unclear. Turbulent flows are inherently intermittent, multi-dimensional phenomena, which create a highly dynamic system occurring on multiple length and time scales. In addition, scalar transport is likely coupled to the highly non-linear velocity field in a spatially and temporally complex manner. This not only leads to difficulties in developing tractable theoretical descriptions, but also to difficulties developing robust and predictive computational modeling capabilities. New measurement and analysis tools are needed to investigate, understand, and describe the multi-scale and multi-physics nature of the turbulent scalar mixing process. This project will be aided by recent technological advances in quantitative high-speed imaging and in particular, a new multi-kHz, high-energy laser system, which allows simultaneous time-resolved 3D velocity and 2D conserved scalar measurements in high-Reynolds number, gas-phase flows. The project will be transformative through characterization of the dynamic interaction between turbulent velocity and scalar fields in real time. Space- and time-correlation between fluid kinematics and scalar gradients will be quantified. The measurements will be used to investigate the underlying mechanisms governing the so-called "ramp-cliff" formation, which indicates the imprint of large-scale intermittency on smaller scales and persistent scalar anisotropy at all scales. Finally, the unique data sets will enable an investigation into the relative importance of advection and diffusion as a function of time, characterizing the level of intermittency of each process. Temporally based, joint velocity-scalar statistics will allow a new parameterization of the nature of velocity-mixing dynamics. In addition, it is proposed to experimentally determine new, multi-point, multi-time correlations, which are statistical quantities containing both spatial and temporal structural information that can be appropriately compared to both theory and time-dependent modeling results from large-eddy simulation (LES). Broader Impacts: A successful project will have significant impact on the fundamental understanding of scalar mixing in turbulent flows and in the field of turbulence in general. Since the performance of the majority of realistic combustion systems such as gas turbine and internal combustion engines are underpinned by turbulent mixing, a better understanding of the underlying physics can lead to cleaner and more efficient systems. The proposed research also will provide critical, new data to assess turbulence theory and to develop physically based LES models as well as their implementation into realistic turbulent environments. In terms of research-related education, a doctoral student will be supported by this project. Every effort will be made to include the participation of students traditionally classified as under-represented including women and minorities. Additional opportunities for broader impacts will be available through undergraduate honors projects, research seminars, the dissemination of results into the open literature, and through presentations at conferences. This research provides excellent opportunities student participants to work within (and significantly contribute to) a wide range of advanced topics including fluid dynamics and optical diagnostics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulent mixing of flow scalars is ubiquitous in nature and a number of engineering applications including mixing of fuel and oxidizer in an engine (which controls efficiency and pollutant formation) and dispersal of pollutants in urban settings and the atmosphere. The basic phenomenology of scalar mixing dates back to pioneering turbulence work from the first half of the twentieth century. During the next several decades, considerable research was devoted to characterizing the statistical nature of turbulent mixing processes as well as detailing the organizational structure, including the role of large-scale coherent and small-scale dissipative structures. Considerable evidence points to the fact that the classical picture of turbulence may not be sufficient to describe turbulent scalar mixing as research has shown evidence of strong coupling between large and small scales in addition to anisotropy at the inertial and dissipative scales of the scalar fields. Such results reflect the imprint of the large-scalar structure and dynamics on the small-scale mixing processes that may not be captured in classical theories. This highlights the need for high-quality experimentation to not only provide improved insights of the underpinning physics, but also to provide new data for computational model assessment and development.

The research supported by this grant focused on measuring the interaction between flow turbulence and scalar mixing in gas-phase turbulent jets using state-of-the-art high-speed laser diagnostics. Specifically, this research program targeted (i) the development of new simultaneous, quantitative, time-resolved scalar and velocity measurements under high-Reynolds number flow conditions and (ii) development of new turbulence-scalar relationships through spatio-temporal statistics. As a starting point, high-speed tracer planar laser-induced fluorescence (PLIF) was considered for the tracer measurements as it is a common technique at low laser repetition and acquisition rates. However, detailed testing using common fluorescent tracers showed signal depletion effects when the tracer was excited using repetitive laser pulses. Results over a broad range of laser fluence values were used to provide guidelines to community on how to carefully use high-repetition laser excitation of tracers. In a turbulent flow, each fluid element will be hit by a number of repetitive pulses; however, the number is not known due to the stochastic nature of the flow. In this manner, an alternative to the tracer-LIF technique was developed.

In order to facilitate, velocity and scalar mixing measurements, simultaneous time-resolved spontaneous Raman scattering (SRS; scalar) and particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) measurements was developed. The accuracy of the scalar measurements was established using detailed calibrations, measurements in canonical configurations, and comparisons to existing measurements and known turbulent scaling laws. The primary goal of developing the simultaneous kHz-rate PIV and SRS measurements was to examine the space and time correlations between velocity and scalar fluctuations. A range of spatial and temporal statistics were deduced from the data including temporal autocorrelation functions, two-point spatial correlation functions, and two-point temporal correlations of both scalar and velocity fluctuations. The various correlation functions and derived integral scales of both the scalar and the axial component of velocity show a high degree of similarity in both form and absolute value. This indicates that the two quantities have a similar “memory” of the local turbulence and that the scalar concentration is highly coupled to the axial component of the velocity.

A significant utility of the simultaneous velocity and scalar measurements was the ability to perform cross correlations between the velocity and scalar fluctuations. For example, the temporal cross correlation between the measured velocity and scalar fluctuations allows a statistical description of the similarity of the two variables at particular instances in time (or phase) – this has not been available previously. Results from the temporal cross-correlation analysis showed that the maximum correlation between velocity and scalar fluctuations occurred at zero time lag, indicating no apparent time delay (or phase di?erence) between the two signals; that is, the response of the scalar ?uctuations are statistically temporally coincident with the axial velocity ?uctuations. While the results showed that the behavior of the scalar ?eld is largely controlled by the velocity ?eld, the maximum correlation between the velocity and scalar was measurably below unity, implying that the scalar is not strictly “passive” in relation to the velocity ?eld. Most likely, the relationship between small-scale velocity and scalar ?uctuations and the strain and scalar gradient ?elds result in a maximum correlation which is less than unity.
